I.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
 
1.  The Tamil Nadu Urban Flagship Investment Program will develop priority water supply, 
sewerage, and drainage infrastructure in at least 10 cities located within strategic industrial 
corridors of Tamil Nadu;1 support innovative pilot projects; improve urban governance; and 
strengthen the capacity of state and local institutions to enhance environmental sustainability, 
climate resilience, and urban livability.2 It will develop India's first solar-powered sewage treatment 
plant (STP) to offset greenhouse gas emissions and improve operational efficiency, providing 
strong demonstration value. 
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Justification 
2.  Urban challenges in Tamil Nadu. The key urban sector issues in Tamil Nadu are:                  
(i) acute infrastructure deficits and low service levels, with demand for both infrastructure and 
services increasing as a result of rapid urbanization;3 (ii) water scarcity; (iii) environmental 
pollution; (iii) weak capacity of urban local bodies (ULBs) to prepare and implement projects, and 
undertake operation and maintenance; (iv) inadequate tariff revisions for water and sewerage, 
which reduce available revenues and thereby reduce the effectiveness and sustainability of 
assets; and (v) mixed performance in key areas of governance, namely, financial management, 
revenue generation, administration, and gender equality and social inclusion. The Government of 
Tamil Nadu identified capacity building, mobilizing finance for urban infrastructure, accelerating 
innovative approaches and green technologies, and advancing municipal reforms as keys to 
modernizing cities and towns and making them more clean and livable.4 Accordingly, the state 
increased its budget allocation for urban infrastructure to $1.98 billion equivalent (6.0% of the 
total), and for water supply and sanitation to $1.77 billion equivalent (5.4% of total budget) in its 
Twelfth Five-Year Plan (2012–2017).5  
 
3.  Urban  institutional  framework.  The  Municipal  Administration  and  Water  Supply 
Department (MAWS) is the focal state-level department for urban development and responsible 
for  urban  sector  activities  in  Tamil  Nadu,  except  urban  planning  and  housing.  The 
Commissionerate of Municipal Administration (CMA) under MAWS supports cities (other than 
Chennai) to plan and implement urban infrastructure projects, and advances the urban reform 
agenda under the Constitution (Seventy-fourth Amendment) Act, 1992 in key areas of planning, 
development, revenue generation, financial management, and service delivery. The ULBs and 
city corporations are the local government entities mandated to provide basic urban services to 
its residents, with powers of taxation and revenue generation. 
 
                                                
1  The project will include the following city and city municipal corporations, and municipalities (collectively referred to 
as cities): Ambur, Chennai, Coimbatore, Cuddalore, Rajapalayam, Thoothukudi, Tiruppur, Tiruchirappalli, Tirunelveli, 
and Vellore. Other cities are eligible for support under the multitranche financing facility subject to complying with the 
city and subproject selection criteria outlined in the Framework Financing Agreement.

2 
   
4.  Institutional capacity gaps. The Government of Tamil Nadu identified strengthening 
capacity of ULBs and urban governance as priorities to improve performance in the urban sector. 
Key institutional challenges are (i) weak capacity of ULBs to plan, design and implement projects 
in a timely, cost-effective manner, and to sustainably operate and maintain such facilities; and (ii) 
the weak capacity of CMA to support ULBs. ULBs find it difficult to mobilize sufficient human 
resources because of restrictive hiring rules and procedures, and rely increasingly on CMA to 
provide investment planning and implementation support. Because funding is provided by the 
government,  CMA’s  need  for  appraisal  and  approval  capacity  has  also  increased.  Future 
investments will rely on ULB and CMA capacity to develop and execute projects. By strengthening 
the capacity of the CMA to support ULBs, the capacity building technical assistance (TA) will 
strengthen key urban institutions required for improved sector performance.   
 
5.  Commissionerate of Municipal Administration, engineering wing. CMA’s engineering 
wing  is  responsible  for  planning,  designing,  coordinating  and  supervising  all  the  urban 
infrastructure investments in ULBs (except Chennai), with their responsibility varying with the ULB 
size. CMA undertakes review and technical appraisal for large municipal corporations, and assists 
with design, procurement and implementation for small ULBs. The engineering staff includes 
three executive or higher-level engineers, and eight junior engineering positions. The capacity 
and resources of CMA’s engineering wing needs to be strengthened to effectively support ULBs. 
Design, preparation, and implementation of ULB investments was previously carried out by state-
level agencies with engineering capacity (e.g., the Tamil Nadu Water and Drainage Board); 
CMA’s responsibilities were moderate, and the current structure was adequate and sustainable. 
However, CMA is taking increasing responsibility for implementation in new areas (e.g., solid 
waste management, fecal sludge management, and urban transport work) that are outside the 
domain of other state-level agencies, as well as handling basic urban services such as water 
supply and sanitation. In addition, responsibility for project implementation in general is being 
transferred from government-owned corporations to larger ULBs, as part of the gradual devolution 
process under the Constitution (Seventy-fourth Amendment) Act, 1992. These trends will continue 
and the demand for project preparatory and implementation capacity support from CMA will 
increase. Since fiscal year 2010, the compound annual growth rate for capital expenditures for 
ULBs financed through MAWS was 21.9%.6  
 
6.  Commissionerate of Municipal Administration project design and management. 
CMA will establish a dedicated project design and management cell (PDMC) responsible for 
supporting ULBs in planning, design, supervision and project management, along with other 
advisory  services  in  planning  and  development.  It  will  initially  be  staffed  by  redeploying 
engineering staff in the CMA and ULBs, with no new recruitment proposed in the short term. The 
program will support CMA in establishing the PDMC by: (i) funding required software and 
equipment (investment component); and (ii) strengthening capacity (grant component) through 
training,  exposure to  best  practices,  and  by  preparing manuals  and other  required  design 
guidelines. 
 
7.  Urban governance gaps.  The Government of Tamil Nadu identified the following areas 
for improvement (i) financial management (i.e., large number of unresolved audit observations);7 
(ii)  revenue  generation  (i.e.,  49%  collection  efficiency  of  user  charges  for  sewerage);8  (iii) 
administration (i.e., 18.8% vacancy in key positions); and (iv) scaling up new approaches (i.e., 
                                                
6  MAWS Policy Note 2009-10, MAWS Demand for grants 2017-18. 
7  As of June 2017, more than 148,672 audit observations were pending resolution. 
8  Low connection coverage is an issue—71.1% of households are connected to sewerage and water networks, as 
compared to the project targets.

3 
fecal  sludge  management  and  wastewater  reuse).  While  the  state  has  other  government-
supported  performance-based  reform  programs,  their  geographic  coverage  and  scope  are 
narrow. For example, the incentive fund recommended by the Fifth State Finance Commission 
focuses only on property tax, with other user charges excluded. The Atal Mission for Rejuvenation 
and Urban Transformation targets reforms in cities with populations over 100,000, excluding 
smaller ULBs. No incentive fund covers all ULBs in Tamil Nadu, resulting in unbalanced sector 
performance. 
 
8.  Urban data and governance improvement. In response, CMA will establish a new urban 
data and governance improvement cell, which will be responsible for (i) collecting and analyzing 
data on key governance parameters (finance, administration, service delivery, gender) of all ULBs 
in  the  state;  (ii)  conducting  research  into  key  performance  areas;  (iii)  administering  the 
performance-based  governance  improvement  program  under  the  program;9  (iv)  providing 
advisory services to ULBs in governance improvement; and (iv) providing Government of Tamil 
Nadu with real-time data and analytics for policy making, budget planning, and allocations. The 
program will support CMA in establishing and strengthening the capacity of this unit by: (i) 
providing performance-based funds to provide incentives to improve governance (investment 
component); (ii) providing consultant services and information technology support (hardware and 
software) for administering the governance improvement program under the program (investment 
component); and (iii) strengthening capacity in governance reforms (grant TA component) through 
trainings and exposure to best practices. CMA will engage an independent verification agency to 
conduct  annual  performance  assessments,  regular  data  collection,  field  verifications  and 
recommend incentive payouts.10  
 
B.  Outputs and Activities  
 
9.  Output 1: Institutional capacity of the Commissionerate of Municipal Administration 
to support urban local bodies prepare and scale up urban infrastructure projects in Tamil 
Nadu strengthened. Under the first output, key activities include (i) provide training, support, and 
exposure visits to PDMC staff to strengthen capacity in preparing feasibility studies, detailed 
project report proposals, engineering designs, innovative approaches in planning and sustainable 
services delivery—spatial and land use planning, geographic information system technology, 
smart applications, energy efficiency, and nonrevenue water management—and operation and 
maintenance of urban infrastructure;11 and (ii) prepare design manuals and standards for use by 
the PDMC and ULBs in preparing new projects. 
 
10.  Output 2: Institutional capacity of the Commissionerate of Municipal Administration 
to implement urban governance improvement programs strengthened. Under the second 
output, key activities include (i) providing training and exposure to best practices in urban 
governance and performance-based governance improvement programs, including converting 
data into useful policy recommendations; and (ii) supporting CMA in drafting policy notes that use 
data analysis results.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
11.  The TA is estimated to cost $1.1 million, of which $1.0 million will be financed on a grant  
                                                
9  CMA has experience in administering conditional grant release under the 13th and 14th Finance Commissions, and 
the Model Cities component of the World Bank-funded Tamil Nadu Sustainable Urban Development Project. 
10 Independent validation is included in the terms of reference of the urban governance improvement and awareness 
consultants under the Tamil Nadu Urban Flagship Investment Program.  
11 Capacity building under output 1 may also include project implementation support to project ULBs, as required.

basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-Others). The eligible expenditure items 
are (i) hiring national and international experts in relevant fields for preparing manuals, standards, 
and providing advisory services; (ii) training and workshops for relevant state and local officials; 
and (iii) national and international exposure visits for relevant state and local officials.12 The 
government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office accommodation 
for consultants, space for training and workshops, and other in-kind contributions. The detailed 
cost estimates for the grant are in Appendix 1.   
 
12.  The TA proceeds will be disbursed in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time).  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  The ADB will administer the TA. The Urban Development and Water Division of ADB’s 
South Asia Department will select, supervise, and evaluate consultants. The executing agency is 
MAWS, acting through Tamil Nadu Urban Infrastructure Financial Services Ltd. The CMA will be 
the implementing agency for the TA, which will be implemented over 30 months (September 2018 
to December 2020).

14.  The TA will require about 48 person-months of consulting services (about 10 person-
months of international and 38 person-months of national services).13 ADB will engage a mix of 
consulting firm and individual consultants in accordance with the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, 
as amended from time to time) and the associated project administration and TA staff instructions. 
A team of experts in a firm will be recruited by ADB using the quality-and cost-based selection 
method with a quality-cost ratio of 90:10, and individuals  will be recruited using individual 
consultant  selection.14 A  full  technical  proposal  will  be  used  for  the  selection  of  a  firm.
